entry.summary: What is the Client-Server Model? â¦ In order to build database-backed web applications, we first need to understand how servers, clients, and databases interact. â¦ A server is a centralized program that communicates over a network (such as the Internet) to serve clients. â¦ And a client is a program (like the web browser on your computer) that can request data from a server. â¦ When you go to a web page in your browser, your browser (the client) makes a request to the serverâ€”which then returns the data for that page. Relational Database Clients : â¦ A database client is any program that sends requests to a database. â¦ In some cases, the database client is a web-server! When your browser makes a request, the web server acts as a server (fulfilling that request) â¦ But when the web server requests data from the database, It is acting as a client to that databaseâ€”and the database is the server (because it is fulfilling the request). Servers, Clients, Hosts : â¦ In a Client-Server Model, a server serves many clients. â¦ The Client can be (Commands line Applications, Graphical users interfaces, Web App). â¦ Servers and clients are programs that run on hosts. â¦ The server sometimes refers to both the computer and the process that serves the web app â¦ Hosts are computers connected over a network (like the internet!). â¦ The host (computer) of the web server and the database, can be the same computer. Requests and Responses : â¦ A client sends a request to the server â¦ The server's job is to fulfill the request with a response it sends back to the client. â¦ Requests and responses are served via a communication protocol, which sets up the expectations and rules for how the communication occurs between servers and clients. Note: Don't let this confuse you. Since a web server can do both, it sometimes acts as a server and sometimes acts as a client :).

entry.summary:
As video conference calls are now part of my daily life, I decided to investigate how I can look better in front of my webcam. After some research, I bought an Elgato Key Light Air to help illuminate my face better. So far, I'm delighted with the purchase. The key light has definitely improved how I look on video calls. But having to turn it on every time I have a video call and then turn it off when the call ends is a pain. I then put on my software engineering hat and wondered, "Can I automate this inconvenience away?". As it turns out, I can. The Elgato Key Light and Key Light Air devices actually have a web server (listening on port 9123) built in. The web server exposes a REST API: GET /elgato/lights
This endpoint returns the status of the key light. Sample Response { "numberOfLights": 1, "lights": [ { "on": 1, "brightness": 9, "temperature": 262 } ] }
For updating the key light, there's a PUT action endpoint: PUT /elgato/lights
Content-Type: 'application/json' --data-raw '{ "Lights": [ { "Temperature": 344, "Brightness": 100, "On": 1 } ] }'
This endpoint allows you to set the attributes of the key light. You can set the brightness and temperature, including turning it on or off. This means that I can turn the Elgato Key Light off and on by interfacing with its REST API endpoints. I created a Node.js script that toggles on and off the Elgato Key Light. I then bound the execution of the script to a keyboard macro. So now, I can tap a key to turn the Key Light on and off.Â :D It is relatively easy for one to interface with an Elgato Key Light or Key Light Air using its built-in REST API. entry.title: Some thoughts about productivity
entry.summary: For the last couple of years, I have been in the Linux space and mostly tried to find the best distro, best file manager, best terminal etc. I was caught up in the loop of finding the best programs to handle a job. This approach, unless controlled, usually leads to low productivity in the long term. How so you might askÂ ? Well, this behavior is really relatable for some people. When I am talking about this subject, some of you might probably say, "Oh yes I have been there". In Linux world, there is even a term for this. Ricing. Ricing means tweaking the configuration of your working environment to suit your personal needs. At particular level, one might consider this useful, and it indeed is. There are some workflow approaches, shortcuts and others that helps the developer access files and folders faster, learn by muscle memory and perform some set of actions quicker. Past that particular level and you are now in the over-ricing zone. Where you are essentially tweaking every aspect of each program, work environment to your needs, but at the same time you are never satisfied so you keep tweaking and changing settings, configs and what not. It reduces your productivity and at the end of the day when you look back, you realize you have done nothing but tweaking some stuff to find the best work environment. This is what I call the loop (referring to the Bandersnatch here). You are in the loop. You need to get out and you need to get sh*t done. Don't worry about using the best tool out there, don't try to find the absolute efficient program. Just get it done. This is in actuality a paradox. The paradox goes as such, "The more choices you have, the less satisfied you are". Seems about right when you think for a bit.
